title: Fuel Tank - Installation

body.body: Observe the warning advice given in the General Information section on the safe handling of fuel and fuel containers.
A fire, causing personal injury and damage to property could result from spilled fuel or fuel not handled or stored correctly.
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall, causing injury to the operator or damage to the motorcycle.
Make sure that the fuel hose is correctly routed. If the fuel hose is incorrectly routed, it can become kinked and reduce the fuel flow. This can cause the engine to misfire or stop.
A dangerous riding condition leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident could result if this warning is ignored.
Fuel Tank Installation Except DEX DG4 DD4
Make sure the front and rear mounting rubbers are correctly fitted.
Manoeuvre the tank into position, engaging it with the front mounting rubbers.
Reconnect the fuel feed hose by gently pushing inwards until the hose engages with a click.

body.name: Disconnect fuel line from fuel rail ciwd

body.body: Slide the double check latch to the locked position until the release buttons are covered. If the latch will not slide into position, then the fuel hose is not fully home on its spigot and must therefore be refitted correctly.

body.name: Fuel line double check clip cekp_1

body.body: Attach and connect the breather pipe to the fuel tank.
Connect the electrical connectors for the fuel pump and the fuel level sensor to the main harness and attach them to the ignition coil bracket.
Lower the tank into position ensuring the breather pipe is not trapped, kinked or twisted.
Refit the rear fuel tank mounting retaining bolt.
Fit a new locknut, counterhold the bolt and tighten the new lock nut to
If removed, use a proprietary professional automotive workshop equipment approved for fuel handling, to refill the fuel tank with any fuel removed earlier.

Observe the warning advice given in the General Information section on the safe handling of fuel and fuel containers.
A fire, causing personal injury and damage to property could result from spilled fuel or fuel not handled or stored correctly.
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall, causing injury to the operator or damage to the motorcycle.
Make sure that the fuel hose is correctly routed. If the fuel hose is incorrectly routed, it can become kinked and reduce the fuel flow. This can cause the engine to misfire or stop.
A dangerous riding condition leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident could result if this warning is ignored.
Make sure the front and rear mounting rubbers are correctly fitted.
Manoeuvre the tank into position, engaging it with the front mounting rubbers.
Reconnect the fuel feed hose by gently pushing inwards until the hose engages with a click.
Fuel hose

Slide the double check latch to the locked position until the release buttons are covered. If the latch will not slide into position, then the fuel hose is not fully home on its spigot and must therefore be refitted correctly.
Locked Position
Unlocked Position
Attach and connect the breather pipe to the fuel tank.
Connect the electrical connectors for the fuel pump and the fuel level sensor to the main harness and attach them to the ignition coil bracket.
Lower the tank into position ensuring the breather pipe is not trapped, kinked or twisted.
Refit the rear fuel tank mounting retaining bolt.
Fit a new locknut, counterhold the bolt and tighten the new lock nut to
8 Nm
If removed, use a proprietary professional automotive workshop equipment approved for fuel handling, to refill the fuel tank with any fuel removed earlier.
Perform the following operations:
Battery - Installation
Seat - Installation
